page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY (SINCE 1840)
page.content: {Chelford}is a village which has moved. Up to the 1840's it was at the junction A535/537.Early in the 1840's a railway was planned passing to the East of the village. Mr Dixon -a local landowner-opposed this and the railway took its present line with a station as close as possible to the village. The station area was given an inn - Dixon Arms with coaches to Knutsford and Macclesfield-and some cottages. Since then,the village has moved its centre westward with the station area acquiring a cattle market,shops,bank, further housing (private and council), government cold store(food), health centre and a garage.This new area is now considered to be Chelford,rather than the original site which is the home of only the Church,Post Office and School.A new school is planned for this 'new'area in the 1990's.
